entry.et: Dutch or Low German daler, from German Taler, short for Joachimstaler, from Sankt Joachimsthal, Bohemia, where talers were first made

def.dt: :any of numerous coins patterned after the taler (as a Spanish peso)
:any of various basic monetary units (as in the United States and Canada) see money table
:a coin, note, or token representing one dollar
:money obtained from a specific source the tourism dollar
:compensated by a token salary usually for government service a dollar–a–year man
:investment in a security at regular intervals of a uniform sum regardless of the price level in order to obtain an overall reduction in cost per unit called also dollar averaging
:a day on which special low prices are offered
:diplomacy used by a country to promote its financial or commercial interests abroad
:diplomacy that seeks to strengthen the power of a country or effect its purposes in foreign relations by the use of its financial resources
:a mark $ placed before a number to indicate that it stands for dollars called also dollar mark
:a basic monetary unit shared by a number of islands of the British West Indies
:a coin representing one half of a dollar
:a 1780 silver trade coin used in the Middle East
:any of numerous flat circular sea urchins (order Clypeasteroida) that live chiefly in shallow water on sandy bottoms
